bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 16, 1941

div1.p: Truby informs Hench that he will send photographs under a separate cover. He appreciated Hench's comments on his manuscript, but he doesn't agree with all of his views about what happened in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, January 16, 1941
div1.opener:
answered 1/19/41
in England.
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Jan. 16 '41
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
The well packed & sealed mms. came this
P.M. in perfect condition. You evidently consider
it more precious than I do, but of course
I realize neither of us would like to have it lost.
I wrote you on Sunday (12th) and you no
doubt have the letter by this time. One of
the 4 letters mentioned evidently was lost for
I certainly acknowledged receipt of the W & J
program. If you cant find it I think it
will come back to me in time as my
name & address is on the back, I may
have misdirected it, but dont think so-

Under separate cover I will send
you a photo. of myself taken when I
retired in 1935. Compare this with the
boy (Truby) in the photo. of the detatchment
at Columbia Bks. in 1900- I will be 70
in July '41-so I have a right to show a little
age.

With the photo. I will also return your
photos. of the model and also those which came with
them in your long letter of Jan 7th I took
the liberty of cutting up one of the (model) photos.
and have pasted thenthe pieces on a sheet of paper as
they should be. I am delighted with the result.
AC
T
for I can assure you that it is not for
wrong- I wish you could send me
a few copies of each of those photos.
(model) so that I can makemount some more
to send to some of the old men for
their advice inspection. I have been getting
some real help as I wrote you in
one of those 4 letters mentioned. I hope that
was not the missing letter. Briefly, I said
that I was wrong about Ames using the
tents for the Camp Lazear y. f. cases. He used
the 4 shacks then instead of tents. The shacks
were originally used by the 2d Div. Hosp. of
the 7th A. Corps for Small-pox cases. I had
completely forgoten them but remembered them
when those quiescent cells in my old head
were tickled up a bit by younger men on
men too who actually worked in them-
I think I can find out where (in which building
18 - 19 - 22 or 23) Lazear died. Of course
it might have been in a framed tent as
I first thought. When I get I will leta little more
info. I will redraw the plan of the hospital
and send you a copy-

When you recieve my letter of the 12th I am
sure you will cease worrying about the
comments you made about my mms. I
enjoyed every one of them, but dont agree
with you in all of your views about what
happened in Cuba. You will find that you
will have to spend more than a year before
3
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
you will be able to get to the bottom
of it all. You have a fine start and
have dug up some wonderful information.
But there is much to be uncovered I
am sure- I know I can help you
locate official reports and other sources
of info- I have never had time to do it.

I am not quite sure about Pinto's room
in our bachelor bldg. In time I will find
out. I will explain how Reed happened to have
the end room when I answer your long
letter. There is no mistake about that point
being absolutely correct.

General Brooke died about a month ago.
A dissecting aneurysm which extended down
to the bifurcation and then ruptured into the
pericardium. When we get all the “dope”
I will be able to have the model assembled
properly. I think I should supervise that
myself by going to Carlisle and actually
seeing it done. I agree that it is
important. It should be arranged exactly
as it was in 1900. The 1906 status of
that hospital is of no interest historically.

There were no buildings between the La Plaza
road & the R R track except the disinfecting
plant. No buildings on parade ground except
bks. at west side. When I get some more
copies of the model I can place the barracks where
AC
T
they belong. I did not want to cut up this
photo. too much on you could not figure out
just how I did it. There were very few cuts
by the scissors as you will see-

I am very glad to have you send
anything to Gen. Kean. Send him my letters
if you like. Anything between Kean and
you & me is general property in so far
as I am concerned-

As soon as I can work on that massive
reply to your big letter I will do so-

The barracks belonged to our medical
detatchment. The barracks of the main
post consisting of the 7th Cav., 8th Infty and
2 batteries field Artillery were East of us. from
A quarter of a mile to the nearest and a mile to the Far
East End of the long row of buildings.

I still think that our buildings at the
hospital ran almost north & South- Of course I
can see that a straight line to the gulf-shore
line was N. W. From our porch the north
star was only a little East of north as I
remember it.

Will send this air mail but the photos.
will come the regular way (by train)

I get quite a kick out of all
this and am glad to find you do
also.
